title: USS Yokes (APD-69)
text:
USS "Yokes" (APD-69), ex-DE-668, was a <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> <a href="high-speed%20transport">high-speed transport</a> in commission from 1944 to 1946.
Namesake.
William John Yokes was born n 15 November 1918 in <a href="Franklin%2C%20Pennsylvania">Franklin</a>, <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>. He enlisted in the U.S. Navy at <a href="Cleveland%2C%20Ohio">Cleveland</a>, <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a>, on 3 January 1942. Yokes was a <a href="Seaman%20%28rank%29">seaman</a> second class attached to the <a href="Naval%20Armed%20Guard">Naval Armed Guard</a> detachment aboard the <a href="merchant%20ship">merchant ship</a> SS "Steel Navigator", a straggler from <a href="Convoy">Convoy</a> ON-137, in the <a href="North%20Atlantic%20Ocean">North Atlantic Ocean</a> in October 1942. For several days, heavy seas and high winds had caused a dangerous shift in <a href="ballast%20tank">ballast</a> in "Steel Navigator". Yokes and his shipmates volunteered to go below and perform the physically exhausting task of shifting ballast to trim the ship, working for some 30 hours without rest.
On 19 October 1942, the attacked "Steel Navigator". <a href="Lookout">Lookout</a>s aboard "Steel Navigator" spotted "U-610"s <a href="periscope">periscope</a>, and the Naval Armed Guard unit swiftly manned its guns and opened fire. Soon the gunfire registered several near-misses on the periscope, and "U-610" withdrew temporarily. Later that day, "U-610" returned and <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed "Steel Navigator", sinking her immediately. Yokes was among the dead.
Yokes was commended posthumously by the U.S. Navys <a href="Chief%20of%20Naval%20Personnel">Chief of Naval Personnel</a>, who cited Yokes's "courageous and unfailing devotion to duty . . . fortitude, skill and bravery" in conduct "in keeping with the highest traditions of the naval service."
Construction and commissioning.
"Yokes" was laid down as the <a href="Buckley%20class%20destroyer%20escort">"Buckley"-class</a> <a href="destroyer%20escort">destroyer escort</a> USS "Yokes" (DE-668) on 22 August 1943 at <a href="Orange%2C%20Texas">Orange</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, by the <a href="Consolidated%20Shipbuilding%20Company">Consolidated Shipbuilding Company</a> and <a href="Ship%20naming%20and%20launching">launched</a> as such on 27 November 1943, sponsored by Mrs. Charlotte Yokes, widow of the ships namesake, <a href="Seaman%20%28rank%29">Seaman</a> Second Class William J. Yokes. "Yokes" was reclassified as a <a href="Charles%20Lawrence%20class%20high%20speed%20transport">"Charles Lawrence"-class</a> high-speed transport and redesignated APD-69 on 27 June 1944. After conversion to her new role, she was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 18 December 1944 with <a href="Lieutenant%20Commander">Lieutenant Commander</a> Paul E. Warfield, <a href="USNR">USNR</a>, in command.
Service history.
World War II.
After <a href="Shakedown%20%28testing%29">shakedown</a> off <a href="Bermuda">Bermuda</a> and post-shakedown repairs at the <a href="Norfolk%20Navy%20Yard">Norfolk Navy Yard</a> at <a href="Portsmouth%2C%20Virginia">Portsmouth</a>, <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>, "Yokes" steamed to the <a href="United%20States%20West%20Coast">United States West Coast</a> via the <a href="Panama%20Canal">Panama Canal</a>, and arrived at <a href="San%20Diego">San Diego</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, on 14 March 1945. After further training, "Yokes" departed San Diego on 19 March 1945, bound for the <a href="Hawaiian%20Islands">Hawaiian Islands</a>. She made port at <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a>, <a href="Territory%20of%20Hawaii">Territory of Hawaii</a>, on 26 March 1945 and trained at <a href="Maui">Maui</a> with <a href="underwater%20demolition%20team">underwater demolition team</a>s for one week before she departed for <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> service in the <a href="Western%20Pacific%20Ocean">Western Pacific</a>.
Arriving at <a href="Okinawa">Okinawa</a> on 1 May 1945, "Yokes" operated in that vicinity through June, serving in the <a href="Okinawa%20campaign">Okinawa campaign</a> as an <a href="antisubmarine%20warfare">antisubmarine</a> screening vessel, a <a href="rescue">rescue</a> ship, and as an escort ship. On 10 May 1945, her gunners claimed a <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Mitsubishi%20A6M">Mitsubishi A6M "Zeke" (or "Zero")</a> <a href="Fighter%20aircraft">fighter</a> shot down.
"Yokes" moved to the <a href="Mariana%20Islands">Mariana Islands</a> in July 1945, escorting <a href="Landing%20Ship%20Tank">Landing Ship Tank</a> <a href="Flotilla">Flotilla</a> 36 from Okinawa to <a href="Saipan">Saipan</a> between 4 and 10 July 1945 and then briefly anchoring at <a href="Apra%20Harbor">Apra Harbor</a>, <a href="Guam">Guam</a>, before heading for Pearl Harbor, where the ship took on board the 14 <a href="Commissioned%20officer">officers</a> and 79 <a href="enlisted%20men">enlisted men</a> of <a href="Underwater%20Demolition%20Team%2028">Underwater Demolition Team 28</a> on 25 July 1945. She then steamed on to the U.S. West Coast, reaching <a href="Oceanside%2C%20California">Oceanside</a>, California on 2 August 1945. Transferring Underwater Demolition Team 28 to <a href="tank%20landing%20craft">tank landing craft</a> <a href="USS%20LCT-395">USS "LCT-395"</a> upon her arrival at Oceanside, "Yokes" departed Oceanside for San Diego that same day.
Shifting to the <a href="Western%20Pipe%20and%20Steel%20Company">Western Pipe and Steel Company</a> <a href="shipyard">shipyard</a> at <a href="San%20Pedro%2C%20Los%20Angeles">San Pedro</a>, California, on 5 August 1945, "Yokes" underwent 15 days of repairs there, during which World War II came to end with the <a href="surrender%20of%20Japan">surrender of Japan</a> on 15 August 1945.
Postwar.
Upon completion of her repairs, "Yokes" conducted a brief stint of training off the coast of <a href="Southern%20California">Southern California</a>. She then departed San Diego on 5 September 1945 to return to the <a href="Far%20East">Far East</a>, touching at <a href="Manila%20Bay">Manila Bay</a>, <a href="Subic%20Bay">Subic Bay</a>, <a href="Tacloban">Tacloban</a>, and <a href="Samar">Samar</a> in the <a href="Philippine%20Islands">Philippine Islands</a>, <a href="Buckner%20Bay">Buckner Bay</a> on Okinawa, Guam, <a href="Manus%20Island">Manus Island</a>, and <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="China">China</a>, on transport operations into the winter of 1945–1946.
Departing Manila Bay on 23 January 1946, "Yokes" steamed via Pearl Harbor to San Diego, which she reached on 15 February 1946. She remained there undergoing repairs through the summer of 1946.
Decommissioning and disposal.
<a href="Ship%20decommissioning">Decommissioned</a> at San Diego on 19 August 1946, "Yokes" was berthed there in the San Diego Group of the <a href="Pacific%20Reserve%20Fleet">Pacific Reserve Fleet</a>. After nearly 18 years of inactivity in <a href="Reserve%20fleet">reserve</a>, she was stricken from the <a href="Navy%20List">Navy List</a> on 1 April 1964 and in 1965 was sold to the <a href="National%20Metal%20and%20Steel%20Corporation">National Metal and Steel Corporation</a> of <a href="Terminal%20Island">Terminal Island</a>, California, for scrapping.
Honors and awards.
"Yokes" received one <a href="battle%20star">battle star</a> for her World War II service in the Okinawa campaign.
